titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Ella Fuller Photograph Collection,
ca. 1895-ca. 1912
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
May Davis Hill

physdesc.extent: 0.5 linear feet of contact prints and collected information

did.abstract: Resident of Ypsilanti Township, Michigan. Collection consists of glass negatives and contact prints depicting farm life, the Fuller family and their neighbors and relatives, recreation, houses, and barns

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 1970 by H. Mark Hildebrandt who purchased the negatives at an estate sale. Donor no. 3466

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Ella Fuller Photograph Collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Ella Fuller was born Ella Grace Frisbie on November 9, 1872 in Belleville, a small farming community in western Wayne County. In 1894, she married Ira Fuller and came to live on a farm in Ypsilanti Township. She died in Ypsilanti in 1968.

Soon after her marriage Fuller acquired a view camera and began recording on glass photographic plates the people and environment around her. Although dating is impossible, Fuller was actively engaged in this hobby for the next decade and a half and then stopped.

arrangement.p: The Fuller collection of ca. 240 glass negatives dates from the period of approximately 1895 to 1912. The collection has been arranged into three series: Contact Prints; papers about the Collection, and the Glass Negative collection. The order of the series was partially dictated by the fragility of the negatives and the fact that contact prints have been made of most of the images. The contact prints and papers about the collection are open to research. Access to the glass negatives will be limited to the staff.

scopecontent.p: This collection of visual images taken by Ella Fuller who was not a professional photographer provide a unique glimpse of daily rural life. Through her camera, Fuller recorded the activities of family and acquaintances. She had a natural talent to capture people as they were, at work and at play, thoughtful, interested in what they were doing. As May Davis Hill wrote, "The Fuller photographs provide an unselfconscious, direct view of rural life in a seemingly idyllic period. Reflecting a genre quality, the images record ordinary scenes from everyday life."

The Contact Prints are arranged alphabetically by broad subject theme: children, houses, interiors, etc. Specific descriptions will be found in the listing of the glass negatives which refers to the envelope in which the contact print has been placed.

did.unittitle: Houses, other than Fuller, Derbyshire, and Lowden

scopecontent.p: The files which have been group together as papers About the Collection were gathered together by library curator May Davis Hill who researched and analyzed the Ella Fuller and her work. Included are slide images of some of the Fuller photographs which Hill used in various talks that she gave.

did.unittitle: Research notes of May Davis Hill re collection
Slides of selective images used in presentations about the Ella Fuller collection

scopecontent.p: The Glass Negatives are arranged by the negative number that Fuller gave to them. The descriptions, often minimal because of the paucity of information that came with them, were prepared by May Hill. Included with each description is the envelope number where the contact print may be found. Blank numbers of course indicate images never received by the library. Images of poor quality have had no contact prints made for them. This fact is included in the listing of glass negatives.
